Now Open
Timothy Taylor at Art Basel Miami Beach, booth C28
 
Bright, entrancing colour is the focus of our booth at Art Basel Miami Beach this year, which features a mixture of 20th century masterpieces and captivating works by early-career artists.

Daniel Crews-Chubb (@danielcrewschubb), Jorge Eielson, Armen Eloyan (@cryboy.66), Sam Francis, Adolph Gottlieb, Damien Hirst (@damienhirst), David Hockney (@davidhockneyofficial), Alex Katz (@alexkatzofficial), Jonathan Lasker, Glenn Ligon (@glennligon), Sahara Longe (@saharalonge), Chris Martin (@chrismartin764), Eddie Martinez, Josephine Meckseper (@josephinemeckseper), Gabriel de la Mora (@gabrieldelamora118), Annie Morris (@annie_morris_studio), Richard Patterson, Hayal Pozanti (@hayalpozanti), Jiab Prachakul (@jiab_prachakul), Sean Scully, Kiki Smith and Eduardo Terrazas. 
 
Find us at booth C28 at @ArtBasel Miami Beach 2022 through Saturday, December 3, and see more at the link in our bio.
 
-
 
Installation images, Art Basel Miami Beach, Timothy Taylor, 2022.
 
 
#ArtBasel #TimothyTaylor

Sahara Longe’s Triptych (2022) shines on a Times Square billboard at 48th Street and Broadway.

Longe is featured as one of Artsy’s annual Vanguard, a list of the most promising early-career artists in the world. 

-

Installation images, Sahara Longe, Triptych, 2022, Times Square Billboard. Courtesy of Artsy.

#Artsy #SaharaLonge @saharalonge @artsy

Kiki Smith's new permanent works in Grand Central Madison Station, New York City.

Smith worked with a respected mosaic specialist founded in the 19th century, the German firm Franz Mayer of Munich, to create five glass wall mosaics that reference nature, with a particular nod to the flora and fauna of Long Island. The wild turkeys depicted in her mosaic 'The Spring' are bright and colorful, representing a departure for the artist, who threw herself into a new exploration of vivid hues for the project. 'This was a way to engage with color,' she said of her bustling and eccentric evocations of city life, which are sure to entrance commuters.

Smith and Yayoi Kusama were chosen in 2020 to create works for the New York City subway station, following intense competition. An extension of Yayoi Kusama's surreal and humorous ‘My Eternal Soul’ series of paintings decorates an 120-foot mural of the Grand Madison Concourse. The vibrantly multicolored composition depicts a fanciful cosmic party of sorts, with sun-like smiling faces floating alongside amoeba-esque shapes, one of her now-familiar pumpkins and a mix of abstract forms.

-

1: “The Water’s Way,” a rocky beach scene in mosaic by Kiki Smith, in the new Grand Central Madison terminal.Credit: Vincent Tullo for The New York Times
2: “The Spring,” showing a detail of a mosaic by Smith with wild turkeys. Credit: Vincent Tullo for The New York Times
3: Those passing through the terminal will encounter a 120-foot-long mosaic by the artist Yayoi Kusama: “A Message of Love, Directly from My Heart unto the Universe.” Credit: Yayoi Kusama, via Ota Fine Arts and David Zwirner; Photo by Kerry McFate

#KikiSmith #YayoiKusama #GrandCentral

‘Music is still a big part of my practice, but literature gives me a ton of ideas,' says Honor Titus in a recent profile in Vogue on his new exhibition 'Bourgeoisie in Bloom' at Timothy Taylor, now on view in London.

'Sometimes a certain sentence will evoke a feeling that I just try to make visual.'

Evelyn Waugh's Brideshead Revisited and F. Scott Fitzgerald's The Great Gatsby number among his inspirations for this latest series, which sees young debutantes explore loneliness, longing and teenage hope at glittering parties. 

'I see my paintings as an oasis and as a place transcendent of ideas of race and stigma,’ explains Titus. ‘I want to depict an all-inclusive romance for life.'

-

Installation images, Honor Titus: Bourgeoisie in Bloom, Timothy Taylor London, 2022.

#HonorTitus #Vogue

For artist Chris Martin, glitter adds an essential element often missing from contemporary art: fun. 'As an artist, I was initially dismissive of glitter as a 'craft' material and somehow a cheap trick. But it's wild and beautiful, and I soon came around to the whole new sense of light and movement. I began investigating a range of materials such as pom poms, aluminium foil, pillows, plastic jewels, old clothing, leaves, dried bread and collage of all kinds,' he explained to the Financial Times two weeks ago. 

While working as an artist therapist at a treatment program for men and women living with AIDS in Red Hook, Brooklyn in the 1980s-90s, artist Chris Martin became inspired by how his patients used glitter and craft supplies. Like Chris Ofili and other artists, reclaiming glitter as a painting material became a way to transcend old hierarchies of art production as limited to the upper classes, subtly overturning its kitsch associations and reveling in the beauty of art made by outsiders. 

Glitter has a celebratory quality, a joyfulness that dazzles the eye and mind, but it also suggests metaphors for the celestial sky, the mirage between the Internet and reality, and childlike joy. 

-

Chris Martin, After Midnight, 2021. Courtesy of Timothy Taylor, London / New York.

@fthtsi #FT #ChrisMartin

Scenes from Alex Katz’s career-sweeping retrospective at The Solomon R. Guggenheim in Manhattan, New York. Frank Wright’s historic rotunda is the appropriately postwar architectural setting for a dramatic introduction to the most steadily productive artist who emerged in that period.

Curator Katherine Brinson uses the museum’s sweeping curves to walk us through how Katz developed from student artist - sketching passersby on the train - to outsider on the Ab-Ex scene, to towering figure of the 21st century figurative art movement. 

1: Installation view, Alex Katz: Gathering, Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, October 21, 2022–February 20, 2023. Photo: Ariel Ione Williams and Midge Wattles © Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation, New York

2: Alex Katz, Lake Light, 1992. Oil on linen, 66 1/4 × 78 1/4 inches (168.3 × 198.8 cm). Sammlung Stiftung Kunst und Natur, Bad Heilbrunn, Germany © 2022 Alex Katz / Licensed by VAGA at Artists Rights Society (ARS), New York. Photo: Courtesy Sammlung Stiftung Kunst und Natur, Bad Heilbrunn, Germany

Wishing a very happy birthday to #ArmenEloyan.
 
Noted for his large-scale, irreverent paintings of anthropomorphic animals and figures, Armen Eloyan depicts absurd narratives in his darkly existential work. Though Eloyan doesn’t define himself as a writer, his paintings tell sardonic, sometimes erotic stories. His works are heavily impastoed with colourful paints and thick black outlines, adroitly balancing dark humour with a searing existential vision.
 
Eloyan was born in Yerevan, Armenia in 1966 and grew up in the former Soviet Union fascinated by parodies of the human form, from TV cartoons such as Donald Duck to Modernism influences like Philip Guston.
 
‘Cartoons parody the culture, they reflect it in a way that’s entertaining but also profound,’ he says of his lifelong fascination. ‘How humans behave like animals sometimes – how ridiculous politics can be.’
 
Armen Eloyan in his studio, 2017.

@cryboy.66

Thick lines of dark, light and richly coloured paint contour the figures in Sahara Longe's paintings, seen here on view at Alexander Berggruen Gallery, New York. 

The figures in her paintings are isolated, painfully separate from each other, yet imbued with their own individual spark. Her figures' flat gazes reveal little, suggesting an extended alienation within their jewel-bright environments. 

For Longe, these tensions and withheld meanings reflect our everyday desire to explore the unseen beneath the seen, revealing the secrets kept by strangers whose secret lives elude us.

6 December 2022 – 11 January 2023

@saharalonge
@alexanderberggruen

-

Detail of Sahara Longe, Street scene, 2022. © Sahara Longe.

Installation image, Alexander Berggruen Gallery, New York, 2022. © Photography by Dario Lasagni.

Today would be the 99th birthday of the late Catalan artist Antoni Tàpies (1923 - 2012). 

In the late 1940s, Tàpies began working as a surrealist painter, influenced by his friends and mentors Paul Klee and Joan Miró. By the mid-1950s, however, he had created his own distinctive style: gouging, scratching, and incising letters, signs and numbers into canvases coated in sand, dust and clay. His paintings hint at the importance of matter in the humblest of things: a grain of sand contains the infinite, lasting thousands of years longer than a human life. In his work, marks as humble as fingerprints or graffiti suggest the presence of eternity: death, life and rebirth,  things `beyond the wall" or "beyond the tàpia (meaning wall in Catalan)", often signified by the presence of lines or wall-like canvases. 

We are delighted to announce a solo exhibition of late paintings by Antoni Tàpies at Timothy Taylor London, opening this January to celebrate the centennial birthday of the great postwar artist.

Antoni Tàpies, Barcelona 1991. Photo: Raphael Gaillarde via Getty Images.

Over his 50-year career, #PhilipGuston (1913–1980) shifted from figuration to abstraction and back again. 'Philip Guston Now', the first retrospective of the influential artist’s work in nearly two decades, features a diverse selection of paintings, drawings and prints from public and private collections.

Exhibition highlights include foundational paintings from the 1930s that have never been on public view; a cycle of major abstract paintings of the 1950s; a multi-part array of small panel paintings from the late 1960s as Guston developed a new vocabulary grounded in ordinary objects and a powerful selection of large, often apocalyptic paintings of the late 1970s that form Guston’s final artistic statement.

Visit ‘Philip Guston Now,’ on view at the @mfahouston through 16 January. The exhibition will then travel to @tate and @ngadc.

@the_guston_foundation

-

Philip Guston, The Ladder, 1978, oil on canvas, National Gallery of Art, Washington, gift of Edward R. Broida. © Estate of Philip Guston, courtesy Hauser & Wirth

Honor Titus’ work, writes Durga Chew-Bose (@durgapolashi) in a recent essay on the Los Angeles-based artist, ‘evokes the holidays’ nostalgic sense of occasion. A version of splendor borrowed from another time, like the synthetic beauty of poinsettias even when they are real, or Darlene Love’s lift-off and boom… Tinsel, tangled lights in cardboard boxes, Nat King Cole’s cool, his “fire” and “choir.”
 
But there’s something else, beyond the pomp ... What is it about Christmas, like the artist’s paintings, that creates an impression of looking in, observing through a glass window the decorated tree, soft and luminous like a memory. What is it about the presentation of joy that obliges remove?’ 

Titus’ shimmering paintings compel the viewer into a world of teenagers attending chic black-tie parties and all the complicated emotions entailed: loneliness, longing, belonging and outsiderness. Their rich, soft colours evoke the cold and rainy winter season: jewel-tones baubles in storefront windows, neon stars decorating a tree. Pop in and take a look to start the holiday season before we close on 22 December for two weeks.

-

Honor Titus, Central Park West, 2022. ©️ Honor Titus.

𝙈𝙖𝙩𝙚𝙧𝙞𝙖𝙡 𝙒𝙤𝙧𝙡𝙙, Sean Scully's first solo museum exhibition in Denmark, is an exhibition of works designed to respond to the architecture, colors and surroundings of the Thorvaldsens Museum in Copenhagen, dedicated to the great Danish sculptor Bertel Thorvaldsen. Three monumental wooden sculptures tower in the front of the museum, while a stack of glossy black Italian Carrara marble veined with gold dominates the courtyard. 

'When Thorvaldsen came back from Italy, a whole flotilla of woodenships came out to celebrate his return,' wrote Scully on the exhibition. 'I thought a wonderful way to interact with the museum would be to make sculpture out of wood, various colored oaks, which makes an oblique reference to the great naval history of Denmark.'

The exhibition also includes several other sculptures and drawings from Scully’s oeuvre as well as iconic paintings such as those from his continued Landline series.

'Sean Scully: Material World' continues until 5 March 2023.

-

Installation images, Sean Scully: Material World, Thorvaldsens Museum, Copenhagen, 2022. © Sean Scully.Photo: Jens Lindhe.

#SeanScully

@thorvaldsensmuseum

𝘼𝙡𝙚𝙭 𝙆𝙖𝙩𝙯: 𝙏𝙝𝙚𝙖𝙩𝙚𝙧 & 𝘿𝙖𝙣𝙘𝙚 at the Colby Museum of Art puts the legendary New York artist’s love of dance on display.

Katz started partnering with theater and dance companies as a costume and set designer in the early 1960s, and he kept at it over the decades. Yet before the Colby Museum show, no other museum exhibition had examined his relationship to the performing arts. The New York Times has described his artistic collaborations with theatre and dance companies as ‘wacky’: For one joint project, Katz playfully scattered cutouts of dogs across the stage for the dancers to dart between. 

The large, spacious dance theatres were also areas in which Katz began drawing inspiration in the 1960s for the large, flat canvases he is known for today, featuring precise figures with a leaping, dancer-like grace. 

-

Installation images, Alex Katz: Theater and Dance, Colby Museum of Art, 2022. 📸 Gregory Rec.

Next up: Antoni Tàpies in London

19 January – 4 March 2023
Private View: 19 January, 6 – 8pm

Timothy Taylor is delighted to present a solo exhibition of paintings and works on paper by Antoni Tàpies (1923-2012) in honour of the late Catalan artist’s 100th birthday. 

The selection of works, dating from 1989 to 2008, see Tàpies return to the essential language of crosses, triangles, open books and wall-like canvases that forged his career in the mid-1950s. 

-

Image: Antoni Tàpies, Recordant, 1999. © Estate of Antoni Tapies.

'Antonia Showering’s first solo exhibition at Timothy Taylor Gallery was a knockout,' writes Katy Hessel (@thegreatwomenartists) in The Guardian's list of the best cultural moments of 2022. 'In her signature umber palette – with hints of green and that classic Alice Neel blue – she puts into visual form the feeling of attempting to hold on to a memory forever. Wrapped in a hazy glow, her paintings can appear at once haunting and ethereal, ghoulish yet protective. Infused with an acidic and muted colour palette, with thick impasto and washy strokes, Antonia’s paintings deal with universal subjects on a personal level.'

We love meditating on Showering's soft, atmospheric paintings in the hazy holiday season, first shown to wide critical acclaim in her inaugural solo exhibition last March at Timothy Taylor London.  Allow us a quick throwback to our favourite beautiful details, if you will.

-

1: Detail of Antonia Showering, Generations, 2022. ©️ Antonia Showering.
2: Detail of Antonia Showering, Best of both worlds, 2021. ©️ Antonia Showering.

#AntoniaShowering @guardian

Happy birthday to the late French artist Pierre Soulages (1919-2022) this Christmas Eve.

-

Pierre Soulages photographed by Interview Magazine. 📸 Patrick Demarchelier.

𝙇𝙞𝙣𝙙𝙚𝙣 𝙞𝙣 𝙎𝙣𝙤𝙬 shows skeletal tree limbs arch across a dark canvas like abstract lines, revealing Katz’s interest in Jackson Pollock’s drip paintings. Specks of flying snow evoke a nighttime blizzard. 

Katz has painted the northeastern American landscape since the 1950s, frequently inspired by his summer vacations in Maine, and winter branches are a particular feature of his paintings from the mid-1990s. Here, the bold simplicity and stark colours show the flat, abstract style that made Katz an early forebear of Pop Art.

-

Alex Katz, Linden in Snow, 1994. ©️ Alex Katz

Kiki Smith's 𝘾𝙤𝙣𝙜𝙧𝙚𝙜𝙖𝙩𝙞𝙤𝙣 (2014) shows a lone woman sitting nude in a thicket of icy trees, a doe curled up by her side. Blue geometric lines like watercolors evoke an icy sky, while leafless branches suggest a cold frost. 

In the 1990s, Smith explored the identity of women marginalized or pushed out of history in myths; from the 2000s, she spun visions of our experience on earth.  𝘾𝙤𝙣𝙜𝙧𝙚𝙜𝙖𝙩𝙞𝙤𝙣 links both themes, part of a quartet of tapestries representing the seasons. This work is early spring. 

In her ongoing series of dreamlike visions of the natural world, Smith has been informed by medieval tapestries such as the Apocalypse Tapestry at the Chateau d'Angers. Advanced digital tapestry techniques yield objects halfway between printmaking and sculpture, with a beguilingly tactile surface rich with glitter.

-

Kiki Smith, Congregation, 2014. © Kiki Smith.

💫 🌙 Celestial bodies are part of Kiki Smith's long-running fascination with the cycles of the earth and its glittering stars, seen here in ‘Shooting Star’ (2015) this New Year’s Eve. 

Images of lunar eclipses, shooting stars, moons and orbs in aluminium and bronze recur in her work of the 2010s and are linked to her growing consciousness of climate change, outlined in her characteristically ethereal style. This sculpture merges physical lightness with extremely intricate metalwork in an image that suggests the human capacity for infinite wonder in the cosmos.

Wishing everyone a happy and healthy 2023!

Kiki Smith, Shooting Star, 2015. © Kiki Smith.

#KikiSmith #NewYearsEve

London-based artist Annie Morris is profiled in Artnet News’ feature on artists poised to break out big in 2023. A large, glistening bronze ‘Stack’ sculpture shimmers in the Provence sunlight at the Chateau La Coste museum in Southern France, which opened this summer. Each colour was hand-mixed and chosen to echo or counter the surrounding French vineyards, filled with lavender fields, olives and grapes.

'I have been following Annie’s work for some time, and have long admired its ability to teeter on the edge between substance and fragility, rendering the highly personal into a universal language of loss,' writes contributor Liz Parks in @artnet. 

‘But there is something about her relatively recent use of bronze as one of her primary mediums for her ‘Stack’ sculptures that I feel has elevated her practice to a new level. I loved her entire show at Chateau La Coste this summer, but it was the one outdoor work, a monumental bronze ‘Stack,’ that emphatically declares Annie’s place within contemporary art history. Standing at six meters tall in a grassy field, just across the way from an iconic Louise Bourgeois Spider, the two works seem to be in conversation with each other, the bold declarations of artists of different backgrounds and generations united in their meditations on motherhood and mourning.'

-

Annie Morris, Installation view, courtesy of Chateau La Coste ©Stéphane Aboudaram | WE ARE CONTENT(S) 2022.

#AnnieMorris @annie_morris_studio

Sahara Longe is named in @fthtsi as one of the best discoveries of 2022 by FT Aesthetes. Known for her immersive panels of well-dressed figures, Longe examines issues of loneliness, alienation and the unspoken in social situations through deliberately flattened paintings in bright jewel shades.

Following her critically acclaimed Frieze London presentation, we’re excited to announce that Longe’s first solo exhibition will take place in June 2023 at Timothy Taylor London, as reported in @telegraph. 

-

Sahara Longe in her Brixton studio. Courtesy of Ocula and Timothy Taylor London / New York. Photographer William Waterworth.

#SaharaLonge

𝙁𝙧𝙚𝙚 𝙁𝙖𝙡𝙡 at the Seoul Museum of Art is Kiki Smith's first solo exhibition at a public museum in South Korea. 

Smith has always opted for a free-spirited approach to her art and its subjects: wandering freely from sculpture, weaving, painting and photography 'akin to the free-fall wandering of the moon's orbit around earth,' as the exhibition suggests. 

Her figures of women are alternately ethereal and animalistic, hysterical and childlike; animals are primal while offering nuanced metaphors for human behavior. Smith's art runs counter to the times, attending to 'all creatures great and small' and expressing a message of peaceful coexistence. As the artist writes, 'I am still in free-fall.'

The exhibition is open until 12 March.

-

1: Kiki Smith, Rapture, 2001. Courtesy of the artist and Pace Gallery. Photograph by Richard-Max Tremblay.

2: Kiki Smith, Worm, 1992. Courtesy of the artist and Universal Limited Art Editions.

 3: Kiki Smith, the light of the world, 2017. Courtesy of the artist and Pace Gallery. Photograph by Melissa Goodwin and Jonathan Nesteruk.

#KikiSmith @seoulmuseumofart

In Conversation | Honor Titus on 'Bourgeoisie in Bloom' 

Artist Honor Titus discusses themes of hope, longing and loneliness behind 'Bourgeoisie in Bloom', his current exhibition at Timothy Taylor, with curator Wells Fray-Smith of the Whitechapel Gallery.

With one week left to go to see this fabulous show, catch it before it closes next Saturday, 14 January at our London gallery located at 15 Bolton Street.

#HonorTitus

Film by @tomgimlette
@honortitus @wellsfs

Jorge Eielson: The Vertical Knot at Esbaluard Museu, Palma, Italy.

An exploration of the late Peruvian artist’s radical quipu form, a system of knotted rope inspired by pre-Colombian communication forms in ancient Peru. Eielson worked on the knot in different forms and colours throughout his life, living mainly in Italy, until he felt its complexities formed metaphors for every aspect of human society and space. Through this, he sought to illuminate the universal that unites all humans - a basic outline of space, like the stars and planets in the sky. 

The exhibition ends on 2 April. 

-

View of the exhibition “Jorge Eduardo Eielson. The Vertical Knot” © Es Baluard Museu, 2022. Photograph: David Bonet

Final Week 📣

Don’t miss your chance to see our current exhibition, 𝘽𝙤𝙪𝙧𝙜𝙚𝙤𝙞𝙨𝙚 𝙞𝙣 𝘽𝙡𝙤𝙤𝙢, a solo exhibition of works by #HonorTitus in London.

Vibrant paintings of young men and women dancing at glittering parties in black-tie explore themes of nostalgia, class and social rites of passage. Titus draws inspiration from diverse historical, literary and cinematic references, ranging from archival photographs of New Orleans cotillions to 'The Great Gatsby' and Whit Stillman’s ‘Metropolitan’ (1990), a romantic comedy following a group of New York debutantes. 

In spite of their beautiful apparel, Titus' figures often appear hesitant in their glamorous surroundings. They clasp hands or wait at the edges of a white-clothed table, empathetic reminders of the joyous but sometimes painful process of teenagers learning how to become adults.

Until Saturday, 14 January.

-

Honor Titus, Portable Prince, 2022. ©️ Honor Titus. 

@honortitus

One week to go until our upcoming #AntoniTàpies exhibition opens on Thursday, 19 January with a PV from 6 – 8pm. 

Rough texture, illegible markings and hidden secrets are key to the late Catalan master’s work, which examined a culture of fiery national identity and voices oppressed under Franco’s dictatorship. Themes of death, sex and clandestine communication characterise the late, great paintings created by the master in the last two decades of his life.

Tàpies has been called the link between postmodern painting and Surrealism. Held in honor of the artist’s 100th birthday, the exhibition speaks poignantly to our own uneasy present under a splintered global order, and remain a powerful influence on later artists who sought to embody the spiritual emptiness unleashed by the post-war period. 

#AntoniTàpies

19 January - 4 March 2023, Timothy Taylor London

-

Antoni Tàpies, Quatre parts, 2008. ©️ Estate of Antoni Tàpies.

Mimicking the vivid, wide-angle display of television, advertising and movie theatres, Alex Katz's paintings are prescient clues to the dominance of celebrity photos and Instagram - decades before the Internet embodied the reign of stylized beauty.

𝙏𝙝𝙚 𝙂𝙖𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙧𝙞𝙣𝙜 at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum takes us through Katz's career, from his early soft naturalism to 'the flattened modernist space of Manet, where his object-like figures occupy a field comparable to the seamless paper of the commercial photographer's studio, and finally to the close-up of cinema and the billboard,' writes Saul Ostrow in @brooklynrail.

Katz's famously cool paintings are distant beyond their vibrant colours, theatrically simple in the vein of Pop painting. Prefiguring the cool minimalism of literature in Brett Easton Ellis and Sally Rooney, they offer no narratives and stories beyond the elusive flatness of the screen. 

𝙏𝙝𝙚 𝙂𝙖𝙩𝙝𝙚𝙧𝙞𝙣𝙜 is on view until 20 February in New York.

-
Alex Katz, Ada and Vincent, 1967. © Alex Katz.
Alex Katz, Rose Bud, 1967. © Alex Katz.

#Guggenheim #AlexKatz @guggenheim #thegathering

Wishing a very happy birthday to #SaharaLonge, born on this day in 1994 in London, UK.
 
Figures in Longe’s rich, soft paintings mingle against flat panels of colour, the quiet dramas of their interior and social lives playing out with playful restrain.

Taking reference from the moody vibrancy of German Expressionism and the luminous realism of Old Master painting, Longe has created her own style on the borders of abstraction and figuration. Women in rose-coloured kitten heels or emerald-green tights seem to float by virtue of invisible red outlines; clothes are painted with a soft shapelessness that contrasts with the sharp geometry of coloured blocks.

@saharalonge 🎈

-

1: Sahara Longe in her Brixton studio. 📸 Bertie Hamilton Stubbs.

2: Sahara Longe, Triptych, 2022. ©️ Sahara Longe.

From the Creek on display at the Albuquerque Museum of Art, drawing inspiration from the natural world of The Catskills mountains in New York, where she currently lives. Smith has long studied the cosmos and how landscape connects to myth in her beautiful, ethereal works of art. Here the Mawignack, the lowlands where the Catskill and Kaaterskill Creeks converge, transforms into a space of cycles, decay, rebirth and the fragility of the environment. 

This special presentation with the artist expands from Smith’s site-specific installation created in the house and studios of the artist Thomas Cole (1801-1848). Across time, both artists, living about a mile and two centuries apart, walked the same land and created work that responds to the Catskills. While Cole’s paintings of Catskill Creek provide images of sweeping landscapes, Smith’s vision locates the singular and iconic life in this same place. Reflecting on creating landscape imagery, Smith stated “I think more about being in a specific place, rather than being in a landscape. A place reveals itself to you over time… a place can hold so many different perceptions and meanings manifesting very different aspects of a place. 

The exhibition runs until January 18th, 2022.

-

Kiki Smith, Sojourn, 2015.

'I just made things about bodies because I could hardly stand being in one. I had a friend who gave me a copy of Gray’s Anatomy and I opened it up and there were fat cells, and I thought, that’s me! I’m a fat cell. Then, nerve endings. That’s me! I’m a nervous wreck ... between the tongue and the anus, the whole of life happens. Everybody is negotiating and navigating bodies in so many ways. You could look at any aspect of your body and see all of society and how people experience themselves—the shame of the body, the exhilaration and joyousness of the body, but also the economics of bodies, of whose bodies are cared for in this society and whose are discarded. The body has everything.'

Kiki Smith in conversation with the acclaimed Irish writer Colm Tóibín in Interview Magazine. Happy birthday, Kiki!

-

Portrait of Kiki Smith, 1994, New York, NY. © Holister Lowe

𝙊𝙥𝙚𝙣𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙏𝙤𝙣𝙞𝙜𝙝𝙩: 𝘼𝙣𝙩𝙤𝙣𝙞 𝙏à𝙥𝙞𝙚𝙨 at Timothy Taylor London
📍 : 15 Bolton Street, W1J 8BG
⏰ : Tonight, 6 – 8pm 

Join us tonight for the opening of an exhibition of late, great paintings by the Catalan artist Antoni Tàpies (1923-2012) in honor of his 100th birthday.

Sacred markings and gritty applications of sand and cement edge these masterful paintings into the realm of sculpture. The lost or erased fragments of history take center stage in this poignant collection of works, which see Tàpies return to the clandestine imagery of protest inspired by his childhood in 1930s Barcelona. 

Tàpies was stricken by the repression of Catalonia under the Spanish dictator Francisco Franco, who forbade its people to write, speak, or bear names in the Catalan language. 

These works from the 1990s and early 2000s feature the original imagery of crosses, triangles and effaced initials he became known for, which, for Tàpies, reminds us of how history is changed or forgotten by its victors.

-

Installation images, Antoni Tàpies, Timothy Taylor London, 2023.

Happy Lunar New Year!

Celebrating Chinese New Year with one of Chris Martin’s psychedelic yet visually reductive paintings.

Large scale works by Martin such as this play on the sensory experience of pattern and scale. Constellations are evoked through colour field painting, with psychedelic illusions and ‘yin yang’ symbolism. 

Here the ‘yin yang’ symbol is taken apart and put back together off-kilter, playing on the traditional concept of balance that the symbol denotes. The combination of yin yang and primary colours also combines here with Martin’s use of numerology; 16 (the number of white dots) which symbolises harmony. 

Martin conflates notions of chaos and harmony, pointing to the disjunction between chaotic contemporary life and the groundings of spiritual harmony in nature and simplicity.

@chrismartin764

#LunarNewYear #YearOfTheRabbit

Chris Martin, Untitled, 2021 – 2022. © Chris Martin.

'Sean Scully recalls the sensual properties of a place or moment and revisits it with paint or through construction,' writes @airmailweekly of Sean Scully's current museum exhibition in Copenhagen, Denmark at the Thorvaldsens Museum. 

As Scully once said of his art, 'My job is to return abstraction to the people: in a sense, to popularize it without lowering the bar, which is a lot easier said than done.'

Until 5 March 2023.

-

We’re delighted to announce representation of Hayal Pozanti (b. 1983, Istanbul, Turkey) in partnership with Jessica Silverman. Her first solo exhibition with the gallery will open in April 2023 in New York, inaugurating Timothy Taylor's new 6,000 sq. ft space in Tribeca.

Over the past decade, Pozanti created an alphabet of 31 ciphers to relate our reliance on technology and numbers in abstract geometric paintings. Following a move to Vermont, Pozanti’s paintings broke new ground with a lyrical form of abstraction in clear, jewel-like colours, fuelled by an ethical urgency to discover a different way of life. 

The original ciphers, which Pozanti describes as ‘building blocks’, evolved into a rich abstract universe in which unknown plants and animals flourish and reign. ‘It comes to seem almost revolutionary in our world to use intuition as a way of making choices,' says Pozanti.

In his art, Antoni Tàpies uses different symbols as a vocabulary for the subconscious and the sacred. Signs appear on his canvases like wall writing, evoking the graffiti of Barcelona under the regime of Francisco Franco, who forbade the Catalan language to be spoken and written aloud. Exiled to the streets, protestors used the city itself as a place for expressing their native language.

The cross is a frequent symbol for Tàpies, a former Catholic who used the symbol beyond its customary religious meaning. It appears as a cross, a gesture and a T, both a signature and an homage to his wife Teresa. Tàpies was fascinated by the eternal, and used the cross as a way to suggest two opposing directions: vertical and horizontal, a plus sign that unites two entities or stands isolated between the voids.

'Tàpies liked mystery. It gives you something to decipher. He would never offer clues as to what something might mean,' explains Natasha Hebert, the artist's daughter-in-law and curator of the exhibition at Timothy Taylor in a recent interview with @monocle_subscriber. These uncanny marks - crosses, arrows, hearts and letters - carry more questions than answers.

Until 4 March.

-

A sculpture by #AnnieMorris lends a pop of colour to Bonnington House, a Jacobean manor that is the heart of Jupiter Artland, a contemporary sculpture garden in Scotland’s Pentland Hills, not far from Edinburgh. 

Built in 1622 as a hunting lodge, Bonnington House had fallen into dereliction by the time it was acquired by collectors Nicky and Robert Wilson twenty years ago. Since then, they have transformed the manor into an internationally recognised art institution, welcoming 1,000 visitors a day six months out of the year.

Jupiter Artland pays special attention to British female artists like Morris or Tracey Emin, whose permanent bronze sculpture 𝙄 𝙇𝙖𝙮 𝙃𝙚𝙧𝙚 𝙁𝙤𝙧 𝙔𝙤𝙪 is on view. 

Imagination runs in rich seams here, where sculptures by the likes of Anish Kapoor and Antony Gormley come face to face with miniature donkeys in the garden. Striped floors and intricate plaster ceilings are just some of the treasures that await inside.

Explore rough textures, sacred graffiti and the hidden world of Catalonian political activism in Antoni Tàpies' late, great works, now online in our viewing room to accompany our exhibition in London. Visit the link in bio to see the works in full. 

Prefiguring the work of Arte Povera by decades, Tàpies found meaning in the humblest grains of sand, ‘the salt of the earth’, in rough-hewn paintings that illuminate the origins of life and death in a time in which religion had lost its resonance and violence cruelly divided the European continent. 

Tàpies’s paintings speak poignantly to our own uneasy present under a splintered global order, and remain a powerful influence on later artists who sought to embody the spiritual emptiness unleashed by the post-war period, such as Jannis Kounellis, Anselm Kiefer, and Julian Schnabel.

John Chamberlain's Voiceaufondre (2009) is a striking white example of the crushed metal sculptures that are icons of the post-war American art landscape. Unlike many of the artist's brightly colored sculptures, Voiceaufondre is silvery and minimal, singular in his oeuvre. Its title is a portmanteau - a typical play on words by Chamberlain, who loved to compress fantastical words into echoes of the compressed structure of his sculptures.

Chamberlain's sculptures hark back to an age in which an expensive car was the unifying goal every family could ascend to, and technology advanced with the Cold War at the speed of light. His work evokes the Space Age - fast cars and domestic appliances that transformed the everyday life of a working citizen, cutting their hours of labor in half, and creating a new culture of consumption. 

The pale colors of this sculpture also recall marble, another playful homage to the baroque sculpture which inspired Chamberlain throughout his life. Crushed metal wrenches upwards, revealing the power and plasticity of metal: every bit as seductive as a draped robe in a marble sculpture by Bernini.

We want the ascendancy of style over substance, as if there were a difference, and frankly, we want to be moved.'

The exhibition ‘Sunrise’ by #AlexKatz opened yesterday at the MAK Center in Los Angeles, in the latest iteration by the 95-year-old artist’s ongoing painting series, which he refers to as ‘splits’. 

Using a cut-out technique, Katz blends inspiration from Édouard Manet’s pictures of hat-wearing women sunning themselves, the fractured imagery of early cubism, and the mass-consumer quality in Rainer Fassbinder’s 1971 film ‘Beware of a Holy Whore.’ 

This immersive portrait depicts Sunrise Coigney, an actress in a long line of bohemian artists, dancers and poets who feature in the great American artist’s work.

Kiki Smith appears in ‘Body Poetics’, a new group exhibition at the Giant Art Gallery in Bournemouth, UK.  

Featuring a range of works made from the 1970’s to the present and across the mediums of painting, printmaking, sculpture, photography, video, performance, textile and sound, ‘Body Poetics’ is a feminist provocation across time and space that explores the outer limits of what a body can be.

Kiki Smith’s work has always had a sense of active taxonomy, an almost universal survey of living things, at first focused on the human form and in the later years on the phenomena of the natural world and the cosmos. Smith’s beautiful, celestially inspired tapestry ‘Visitor’(2015) is a metaphorical expression of her belief in the connectedness between celestial bodies. Smith has long believed in the astrological significance of constellations and in the power of heavenly bodies to affect human events. 

The exhibition runs until 6th May, 2023.

As a pioneer of Art Informel, Tàpies’ use of unconventional materials, such as marble dust, sand and cement, connect with the artist’s desire to draw something unexpected out of the mundane. Working with these volatile and fast-drying materials are deliberate mechanisms on Tàpies’ part to avoid over-intellectualising his work. He wanted to leave space for the unconscious to run free by being forced to work very quickly.
 
Tàpies found meaning in the humblest grains of sand, ‘the salt of the earth’, in rough-hewn paintings that illuminate the origins of life and death in a time in which religion had lost its resonance and violence cruelly divided the European continent.

'Two Worlds Entwined', weaving works by Annie Morris and Idris Khan in a two-person exhibition at Newlands Gallery, Petworth, Sussex. The London-based artists are married and share a studio, working side by side in their life and work to create their distinctly different forms of art.

Idris Khan has explored the idea of palimpsests for a decade - pieces of paper in which writing effaces earlier writings. The melancholy of the past haunts his intricate multimedia paintings, which are often colored a deep, dark indigo that evokes ocean waves.

Hand-painted in raw pigments of ultramarine, ochre and lavender, Annie Morris' bright, colorful 'Stack' sculptures suggest the swell of pregnancy. The artist's irregular columns evoke the Japanese aesthetic principles of Wabi-Sabi, finding beauty in the imperfect and the simple.

A new abstract series sees the artist explore the female figure - a paradoxical symbol of earnest romance and high camp in his work of the last two decades - in swathes of gestural paint. The exhibition title is a tongue-in-cheek reference to the internet site, alluding to the longing and anonymity of seeking sex online.

Patterson paints wet-into-wet for up to ten hours at a time, seeking 'a highly controlled place in which something uncontrolled might happen.' Like Willem de Kooning's late abstract paintings, which sublimate feminine curves into abstract swoops of pink and blue, Patterson's paintings shadow the outline of women drawn from a high-low melange of kitsch photographs and masterpieces, such as paintings by Gustave Courbet and Robert and Sonia Delaunay.

Wishing a happy birthday to Eduardo Terrazas (b. 1936, Guadalejara, Mexico). The artist, architect and urban designer is renowned for his vivid geometric yarn paintings - which analyse globalisation and the links between the cosmos - as well as his creation of the iconic 1968 Olympics logo.

'How can you make a cosmos that you can live within and make it yours?' Eduardo Terrazas asked himself, the inspiration for his five-decade Possibilities of a Structure series (1972-present). Terrazas first began working with the Huichol community in the Sierra Madré range of Mexico in 1972, drawing upon the tribe's ancient practice of translating religious visions to yarn pressed into hot wax.

Happy Birthday to #DanielCrewsChubb!

Taking inspiration from ancient sculpture, religious mythology and modernist art history, Crews-Chubb creates vivid, textured paintings populated by a cast of totemic characters.

Surface and material are central to his collage technique, in which he patchworks canvases with layers of fabric that are, in turn, covered with acrylic paint, sand, pumice, and expressionistic charcoal drawing. Rarely using brushes, Crews-Chubb applies paint with his hands to build labyrinthine layers that emphasize the sculptural form of the canvas. 

As David Pagel of the Los Angeles Times writes, ‘If Crews-Chubb’s paintings were billboards, they’d stop traffic. But there’s more going on than immediately meets the eye. To look closely is to see how deliberately, even carefully, each is made … You don’t need to know what they reference in order to come face to face with their beauty, which is down and dirty and so far from pretty that you might start to think that beauty without a touch of grunge or even ugliness is not all it’s cracked up to be.’

An exhibition of new paintings by Hilary Pecis opens today at David Kordansky Gallery in Los Angeles. 𝙋𝙖𝙩𝙝𝙨 𝘾𝙧𝙤𝙨𝙨𝙚𝙙 presents a selection of lush, saturated landscapes reflecting the mountainous, desert, and urban landscapes commonly associated with Southern California.
 
‘During the pandemic,’ Pecis says in an interview with Jonathan Griffin (@jonathangriffin) for @cultured_mag, ‘it was often noted that I was a still life painter. I wanted to remind people that I also paint landscapes! I spend so much of my time outside. I run 50-plus miles a week. I love being outside.’
 
Pecis tends to paints from photographs she shoots on her phone while running throughout Los Angeles’s streetscapes or through the various trails she frequents in the surrounding mountains and forests. The photos are then referenced and sometimes even printed out and re-imbued with dynamic and vibrant colour, becoming preparatory sketches for future paintings. This process allows Pecis to refine whatever memory she has of a space while traveling through it, as the initial phone image often loses the clarity and vibrancy cast by the Southern California sunshine and mutes the otherwise bright hues that distinguish the region.
 
‘Paths Crossed’ will be on view from 18 March through 22 April 2023 at David Kordansky in Los Angeles at 5130 W. Edgewood Pl.

Happy birthday to #AgnesMartin (1912-2004). 

One of the most influential painters of her generation, Martin left an enduring mark on contemporary art through her elegant, restrained canvases. Characterised by austere grids of muted colour, Martin’s paintings negotiate the confines of structure, space, and the metaphysical through wavering horizon lines. 

'Anger, all the passions, they’re not real,' said Martin in a 1973 interview, referring to her own turbulent emotions. Martin suffered several schizophrenic breakdowns as a young painter struggling to succeed in the male-dominated New York art scene of the 1940s and '50s. She fled to Taos, New Mexico in the late 1960s, opting to channel her emotions into delicate, painstaking minimal canvases that compress the beauty of the Taos landscape. 

'They are what I call the exhaustibles. All the exhaustible things, like anger—you know how quickly it passes. Even the sense of seeing beauty is a very exhaustible thing, seeing it with your eye. If you see something that looks very, very beautiful, but if you kept your eye on that and looked and looked and looked, the beauty would disappear from it, because the eye is exhaustible. But then the inexhaustibles, they’re within the mind, you see. And the beauty that you see within the mind, it really never disappears. They go on forever.'

-

Agnes Martin. Photograph by Michele Mattei. Courtesy of Moma.

A large-scale painting by Honor Titus, 𝙈𝙮 𝘽𝙖𝙗𝙮'𝙨 𝘽𝙧𝙚𝙖𝙩𝙝 (2022), has been acquired by the Dallas Museum of Art (@dallasmuseumart) as part of its public collection.

The painting, which was first exhibited in Titus' recent solo exhibition at Timothy Taylor London in winter 2022, shows a young debutante in a billowing white dress holding a bouquet of flowers - the ‘baby’s breath’ of the playful title. Inspired by the writer James Baldwin's meditations on the the power of peoples' interior lives, this exhibition draws together works by modern and contemporary artists from the museum’s permanent collection who reflect on elements of their interior lives in figurative and abstract work. Fields of bright, swirling brushstrokes enliven Richard Patterson's new series of abstract paintings, 'Only Fans', which is currently on view at our London gallery. 

Playfully titled after the erotic content website, the series displays shadowy female figures and faces buried beneath swirls of magenta and golden paint: a metaphor for both internet censorship and the way digital culture anonymizes its participants. Yet hidden references to Old Master paintings - a nineteenth-century French mythological nude by Gustave Courbet, the Mona Lisa - remind us that art history has always operated on an indistinct longing for anonymous women. 

'If life is lived online, even sex becomes a proxy for the thing it once was, an imitation of reality to be recorded and uploaded. It becomes an advert for something that never happened. My paintings are the opposite. They’re visceral, performative, concrete.’ - Richard Patterson

'Only Fans' is on view in London until 15 April.

-

Installation images, Richard Patterson: Only Fans, Timothy Taylor London, 2023. 

#RichardPatterson

Gabriel de la Mora's solo exhibition 'Horizonte Móvel' (Mobile Horizon) is now on view at Simōes de Assis until 29 April in São Paulo, Brazil.

De la Mora's artworks are composed of fragments: hair, pieces of mirrors, eggshells, shoe soles and butterfly wings that the artist reorganizes in repetitive, even obsessive mosaic paintings. Fascinated by inversions, patterns and DNA, de la Mora is interested in breaking things down to their essentials in a continuous process of emptying a form to reconstruct it before the viewers' eyes. With their delicately arranged surfaces, his works sometimes resemble pixelated images found on the internet, reminding us of our world's meticulous collation in two-dimensional images. 

A frequent visitor to the National Museum of Anthropology in Mexico City, de la Mora has examined the cultural resonance of butterflies in ancient Aztec and Mesoamerican beliefs in a recent series of butterfly wing mosaics (2021-present). ‘Ītzpāpālōtl’ was an Aztec warrior goddess with the physical attributes of an ‘obsidian butterfly,’ ruling over a paradisiac space associated with fertility and death. Artworks like the 914 He.Le., shown above, draw attention to the exquisite complexity of butterfly wings, suggesting the presence of divine patterns in nature.

“Looking at the final selection of drawings from the Parrish collection and my own side by side, it is easy to see the commonality in our approach to this medium. With overlapping subject matter, similar constructs, and a resonance in mark-making, I found a sense of the familiar that fascinated me.” — Eddie Martinez

For "Artists Choose Parrish" at the Parrish Art Museum (@parrishartmuseum), Eddie Martinez paired drawings from his own archives with largely unfamiliar, pre-1970 works by an earlier generation of artists including Wilfrid Zogbaum, Abraham Hankins, and Frederick Stuart Church.

With 14 of Martinez’s works on view, this exhibition celebrates the Museum's 125th anniversary. It showcases the East End’s rich artistic legacy, bringing together 41 renowned artists with connections to the region. Organized in three installations, the exhibition creates a new dialogue between the Museum’s past and future and reveals new perspectives for its collection through the lens of a diverse roster of artists. 

Learn more and plan your visit to the museum through 23 July, via the link in bio.

Eduardo Terrazas's retrospective, "Equilibrio Múltiple," opens today at Museo del Palacio de Bellas Artes (@mbellasartes) in Mexico City.

Terrazas is known for his geometric and expressive figures and for the diversity of his body of work, which touches architcture, urban design, painting, and Mexico's indigenous Huichol yarn technique. 

With 144 works dating from 1968 to present day, organized into four sections focusing on different aspects of Terrazas' practice, this presentation allows the viewer to take a thematic journey through the full breadth of his oeuvre.

Today, His Majesty the King unveiled portraits which he has commissioned from ten leading artists, including @honortitus and @saharalonge, of pioneering members of the Windrush Generation. 

Marking the 75th anniversary of the arrival of the HMT Empire Windrush to British shores in 1948, the portraits now form part of the Royal Collection and will be displayed at the Palace of Holyroodhouse in Edinburgh before moving to @nationalportraitgallery in London in October. Each artist has written a personal essay reflecting on their experience with the sitters, which will join an illustrated publication on the Windrush Portraits Project. 

@bbcarts has created a documentary on the project to commemorate National Windrush Day, including each artist's first-hand accounts of the creative process, their informal meetings with the sitters, and the impact the legacy of Windrush has had on their lives.

🔗 Tap the link in our bio to learn more.

We are pleased to announce the representation of Alicia Adamerovich (@aliciaadamerovich), in collaboration with Kohn Gallery (@kohngallery) in Los Angeles. The artist's first solo exhibition of new work will be presented at our New York space in fall 2024. 

The Brooklyn-based artist works at the intersection of painting and sculpture, engaging a distinctive visual language of biomorphic abstraction that reflects the landscape of the subconscious. Adamerovich builds up her canvases with multiple layers of pumice, gel, sand, and paint, achieving uncanny effects of surface, depth, and atmosphere, while her sculptures are carved from fallen trees. The artist works intuitively and automatically in both media, offering forms that transcend dichotomies—at once fragile and resilient, simple and complex, ominous and radiant. 

Her work is included in a group show, “Dreaming of Eden” on view through 14 July at Timothy Taylor in New York. 

Tap the link in bio to read more.

See works by Eddie Martinez in conversation with leading international contemporaries @ludwigmuseum in Budapest. 

The exhibition, on view through 12 November, explores the ways in which each artist has incorporated the cuteness factor into their own artistic practice: what theories they have drawn on and what forms of representation or evocative devices they have chosen to express the message they wish to convey. 

A lexicon of conventionally "cute" symbols—flowers, toys, and cartoons—emerges throughout Eddie Martinez's oeuvre. Never one to take the familiar at face value, Martinez subverts these icons through distortion and a perceptibly muscular technique. 

"The Cuteness Factor" is on view through 12 November.

The first-ever woman to win the Turner Prize, Whiteread creates works that subvert the function and form of everyday objects and familiar spaces. In this exhibition, the artist presents two objects reminiscent of corrugated iron, painted and placed within a frame. Created out of papier mache and silver leaf, this work illustrates the artist’s use of inconsequential items as she examines the narrative of absence between everyday structures and people.

New paintings by Gabriel de la Mora (@gabrieldelamora118) open our fall program, beginning 31 August at Timothy Taylor in London. Join us for the opening reception from 6 to 8pm! 

Each work featured in “FRAGMENTXS” explores the intersection of nature and abstraction, merging the visual language of modernism with patterns and effects drawn from the natural world. Drawn from four interrelated and ongoing series, these paintings are the result of a repetitive and deeply meditative process, in which De la Mora experiments with the aesthetic and conceptual properties of found materials. 

Plan your visit and learn more about this upcoming show at the link in bio. 

#GabrieldelaMora #TimothyTaylor 
__ 
Gabriel de la Mora, 2,244, 2023; 726, 2023; 2,184 I Mo.Di., 2023; 1,984 He.Le., 2023; 2,184, 2023; 5,535, 2023 © Gabriel de la Mora

An 11.5 foot tall bronze “Stack” by Annie Morris (@annie_morris_studio) has been unveiled outside the West Yorkshire History Centre in Wakefield, Yorkshire, England. 

The sculpture, titled "Bronze Stack 9, Viridian Green," wraps the artist’s brightly coloured globes in vivid blues, deep reds, and vibrant greens. It reflects both the outdoor environment of the city and the natural landscape of the surrounding countryside — a place of inspiration for Morris, who had her first institutional solo show at the Yorkshire Sculpture Park in 2021. 

“The West Yorkshire History Centre holds historical archives including births, marriages and deaths of the West Riding of Yorkshire… These are symbolic themes echoed in my practice from vulnerability and strength, grief and renewal, hope, uncertainty, rebirth, and creativity.” — Annie Morris 

This program is part of the Wakefield Sculpture Trail's new series, which brings an opportunity to experience and engage with world-class contemporary art to the city centre. 

#AnnieMorris 
__ 
Installation view, Annie Morris's “Stack 9, Viridian Green,” 2023, Wakefield, Yorkshire, England, July 2023. Courtesy of Wakefield Council

In just two weeks, on Wednesday 6 September, "Rendezvous in Time," an exhibition of new large-scale paintings by Jiab Prachakul (@jiab_prachakul) opens at Timothy Taylor. This is the artist’s first solo exhibition with the gallery and her first in New York. 

With works produced by the artist in her home in Brittany, France, this presentation explores the construction of identity through intimate moments of recollection and connection. Spanning two rooms that represent cycles of day and night, "Rendezvous in Time "spotlights the quiet contemplation that underscores Prachakul's daily life. 

Join us from 6 – 8 pm for the opening reception, and follow the link in bio to learn more.

Honor Titus's (@honortitus) first-ever institutional exhibition and inaugural solo presentation in China, “Ornamental Distance,” opens on September 13 at the Longlati Foundation (@longlatifoundation).

Titus reframes traditional depictions of bourgeois leisure from a fresh and multifaceted perspective, juxtaposing themes of exclusion and belonging. Bringing together new and recent paintings, this exhibition explores this tension through a series of recurring symbols and is often represented by a motif of ornamental fences, which reject outsiders while disguising this exclusion behind an aesthetic, decorative facade.

Wishing a very happy birthday to Josephine Meckseper (@josephinemeckseper), who was born on this day, August 29, 1964, in Lilienthal, German!

To celebrate, we're highlighting "Scene VI" from the artist's film "PELLEA[S]," at the gallery in 2019. The film adapts Maurice Maeterlinck’s otherworldly play "Pelléas et Mélisande," 1892 for today’s sociopolitical landscape, weaving together fictional scenarios and dramatic footage captured by the artist at the 2017 presidential inauguration and the landmark women’s march that followed. 

With its timeless, illusory, and refractory aspects, the mirrored set defines the mythic space for the love story that unfolds. The set is a complete installation that features elements and props from the movie. 

#JosephineMeckseper

Join us from 6 – 8pm tonight, 31 August in London, as we celebrate the opening of Gabriel de la Mora's (@gabrieldelamora118) third solo exhibition with the gallery, titled FRAGMENTXS.
 
The twenty-four paintings on view are the result of a repetitive and deeply meditative process, in which de la Mora tests the aesthetic and conceptual properties of found materials.
 
“The mimesis of these paintings implies a strategic adaptation: they are the movement of a body that seeks to integrate, dissolve or become invisible in its context.” –– Patrick Charpenel (@charpenelpatrick), Executive Director of New York’s El Museo del Barrio

Throughout this presentation, the artist plays with distance much like a player on a tennis court—a recurring motif for the artist—first approaching close to depict detail and nuance, then stepping back to gain a deeper perspective on the whole.

#AntoniTapies: "My illusion is to have something to transmit. If I can't change the world, at least I want to change the way people look at it."

Marking the 100th anniversary of Antoni Tàpies' birth, a retrospective of the artist's work opens tomorrow at @bozarbrussels. This is the first major exhibition in Belgium to showcase a complete view of Tapies' work. The musuem will feature a selection of 122 works reunited for the first time in several decades, beginning with his "matter paintings'' of the 1950's, continuing through his objects and assemblages of the 1960's and 1970's and varnishes of the 1980's, and concluding with the artist's formal and material experimentation of the 1990's. 

"The Practice Of Art" is on view through 7 January 2024.

Learn more about this prolific artist and his contributions to 20th-century art at the link in bio.

“FRAGMENTXS,” on view through 30 September, consists of twenty-four paintings that explore the artist’s geometric abstractions. Subtle and precise, de la Mora’s paintings illuminate the transformative potential of his materials and the ever-shifting nature of perception.

Jiab Prachakul’s (@jiab_prachakul) new paintings explore the construction of identity and exemplifies the artist’s cool mode of romantic realism in “Rendezvous in Time."

Elevating quotidian scenes through subtle intervention, the works collected here offer intimate scenes reconstructed from Prachakul’s memory alongside those from her current life in France. The canvases reflect the way identity is experienced as a synthesis of manifold selves, past and present, just as they document the process of constructing oneself anew in an unfamiliar place.

Happy birthday to Gabriel de la Mora (@gabrieldelamora118) who was born on this day in Mexico City! De la Mora, whose practice is rooted in balance and notions of Zen philosophy, synthesizes art history, scientific research, and perceptual experimentation to create “paintings without paint.”

In celebration, we’re highlighting, the artist’s latest body of work in “FRAGMENTXS” which features the twenty-four paintings that merge the visual language of modernism—monochrome, geometric abstraction—with patterns and effects drawn from the natural world. Working with salvaged quotidian materials like feathers, egg shells, and butterfly wings, de la Mora adheres these fragments with surgical precision to museum cardboard to create minimal and often near-monochrome compositions.

#GabrieldelaMora #TimothyTaylor

The Drawing Center’s (@drawingcenter) 2023 benefit exhibition, “The Rejectionists”, includes works by Eddie Martinez and over 75 other artists, which will be available for sale in an online silent auction to benefit the institution. Hosted by Pace (@pacegallery), “The Rejectionists” opens 2 November with a cocktail party amid the exhibition.

In Martinez’s 2017 exhibition at The Drawing Center, the artist papered the gallery with thousands of sketches that he changed throughout the exhibition’s run. In addition, several large drawings and paintings were hung on top of these sketches allowing viewers to observe the interconnection between all aspects of his practice. Martinez’ upcoming solo booth for Timothy Taylor at Frieze London—curated by Claire Gilman, Chief Curator of The Drawing Center—builds on the artist’s previous show at the institution highlight Martinez’ singular approach to gestural abstraction.

#EddieMartinez

Next in London ➡️ A solo exhibition of new paintings by Eddie Martinez opens on 12 October at Timothy Taylor. 

Presenting nine large-scale paintings, "Enough" captures the exuberant, propulsive energy that characterizes the artist’s work. For two decades, Martinez has developed a singular approach to gestural abstraction that involves the deep processing of a personal lexicon of idioms and themes. In this exhibition, Martinez transcribes, layers, comingles, obscures, and exaggerates these images—sourced from his own extensive daily output of drawings—onto the canvas.

The exhibition coincides with Frieze London for which the gallery will present a solo booth of Martinez’s work that builds on his 2017 solo exhibition at the Drawing Center in New York.

Follow the link in bio to learn more.

#EddieMartinez: “Drawing for me is nothing and everything at the same time... It’s not an act of effort... It’s just thinking for me, it’s thinking with a utensil.”

Timothy Taylor is returning to Frieze London (@FriezeOfficial) for its 20th anniversary with a booth dedicated to the work of Eddie Martinez. Curated by Claire Gilman, Chief Curator of the Drawing Center (@DrawingCenter) in New York, the presentation builds on Martinez’s 2017 solo exhibition at the institution, for which he mounted large drawings and paintings over “wallpaper” composed of thousands of sketches pinned to the wall for a kaleidoscopic, floor-to-ceiling installation. 

Thousands of sketches will be arranged on the booth walls, over which framed works on paper will hang, salon style. Vivid and riotous, these works reveal Martinez’s deep processing of images culled from his diaristic drawings. 

Preview the works ahead of the fair opening on 11 October, at the link in bio, and visit us at Booth A14.

#TimothyTaylor #FriezeLondon 
__
Photo: Installation of Eddie Martinez: Studio Wall Redux, 2023

"When Loss Makes Melodies," an exhibition of works by Annie Morris (@annie_morris_studio) and Idris Khan opens today at The Pitzhanger Manor & Gallery (@pitzhanger). Showcasing a diverse range of art forms from sculpture and photography to painting and embroidery, this joint presentation highlights the synchronicity between the two artists and the subtle ways their individual practices converge and inspire one another. 

In this show, Morris draws inspiration from life experiences, expressed dramatically in her trademark 'Stack' sculptures. The sculptures, which began in 2014 following the artist’s grief after the loss of a baby, comprise of precarious irregular spheres balanced into columns. These Stacks echo the swell of pregnancy and act as a replica of Morris’ loss. Playful yet poignantly contemplative, each sphere with its vivid hue—ranging from ultramarine, viridian to ochre—suggests a persistence to find joy amid adversity. 

Tap the link in bio to learn more about this exhibition.

#AnnieMorris

Installation view, "Idris Khan & Annie Morris: When Loss Makes Melodies," London, October, 2023 © Pitzhanger Manor & Gallery. Photo: Andy Stagg

Pozanti seeks a trancelike connection between body and mind, shaping the biomorphic forms rooted in her symbolic language into sweeping visions marked by the texture of touch.

Join us tonight from 6–8pm for the opening of Eddie Martinez "Enough," a presentation of new paintings by the artist at Timothy Taylor in Mayfair in London.

Martinez has described the drive behind his recent paintings as a desire to return to his true nature—to inhabit a mode of experience that precedes the influence of visual culture, marketing, or the media. Often, he recycles and reworks imagery from past paintings, cannibalizing his own production and stripping away preconceived ideas from an image to understand it differently. This activity, he explains, reflects his process of reconciling with the past and accepting what’s to come.

The exhibition coincides with the artist's solo booth at Frieze London for which Martinez mounted large drawings and painted works on paper on top of 2,362 sketches pinned to the wall in an immersive floor-to-ceiling installation.

Follow the link in bio to learn more.

The artist’s first solo exhibition with the gallery features paintings that translate aspects of the artist’s reckoning with identity as something that is unfixed and constantly transformed, including one’s senses, relationships, geography, and cultural codes. Though her works are characterized by formal precision and restraint, some passages luxuriate in the folds and drapery of garments or the chaos of overgrown foliage lending the compositions a sense of long exposure and suspended time. The artist has included recorded sounds of her surroundings in France which play in the gallery.

"Ornamental Distance," Honor Titus’ first museum exhibition, closes at the Longlati Foundation (@longlatifoundation) in Shanghai next week on Thursday 25 October. 

Featuring new and recent paintings, Titus (@honortitus) reframes traditional depictions of bourgeois leisure from a fresh and multifaceted perspective, juxtaposing themes of exclusion and belonging. His depiction of Black figures in settings traditionally dominated by white elite society, create an explicit connection between the artist and his figures. Throughout this presentation, Titus plays with distance much like a player on a tennis court––first approaching close to depict detail and nuance, then stepping back to gain a deeper perspective on the whole.

Wishing a happy birthday to Richard Patterson who was born on this day in Leatherhead, Surrey!

To celebrate, we’re highlighting Patterson’s recent show from earlier this year, “Only Fans,” at Timothy Taylor in London. Consisting of thirteen small-scale paintings in a rejection of digital imagery and embrace of the physical, the passionate, and bravado performance of gestural painting, the exhibition title, a tongue-in-cheek reference to the internet site, references Patterson's evocation of primal sensuality wrapped in layers of alienation. The ghostly outlines of Patterson's female figures allude to the anonymity of data as much as the passion of the body, which comes with searching for status and sexuality online.

We are pleased to announce the joint representation of Michel Pérez Pollo (@michelperezpollo) with Mai 36 Galerie in Zurich, Switzerland. The gallery will present an exhibition of new work by the artist in London this November 2023. 

Pérez Pollo’s surrealist works hint at a dialogue between creator and creation. Each composition is conceived using miniature clay models which the artist then relates onto canvas with oil—enlarging, warping, and exaggerating as he paints. This process emphasizes texture and transforms reality into strange, liminal scenes. Sitting atop simple stages, these vaguely biomorphic forms glow in luminous shades of ochre, tangerine, and emerald. While rigorous and academic, his paintings also recall lush memories of the artist’s upbringing in the Caribbean tropics and the vibrancy of his current life in Spain. Attuned to beauty and balance, Pérez Pollo orchestrates light, shadow, shape, and color into a very singular visual poetry.

Read more at the link in our bio.

#MichelPerezPollo #TimothyTaylor

Now on view in London ➡️ Eddie Martinez: Enough 

This presentation of new paintings by Eddie Martinez marks the artist’s first solo presentation in the UK since 2017. Painted between 2021 and 2023, Martinez’ paintings feature art historical references and his own personal lexicon of imagery, including children's toys and Raid bug spray.

Often, recycling and reworking imagery from past paintings, Martinez strips preconceived ideas away from an image in order to understand it differently. Known references emerge and recede from his compositions, depending on where the viewer focuses the eye; none is prioritized over the other. 

Tap the link in bio to learn more.

Presented across two institutions, Ding Yi’s (@dingyistudio) solo exhibition, “Homeland and Journey,” is now on view at the Ningbo Art Museum and Huambo Museum of Art Education. The presentations illustrate Ding’s decades-long journey culminating in a return to the artist’s hometown of Ningbo, which serves as both the reason and inspiration for the exhibition. 

The Ningbo Art Museum exhibition is divided into two sections: “Footprints of the City” examines the history of Ding’s “Appearance of Crosses,” and “Constellations and Recent Works” features the artist’s new “Constellations” series created especially for his hometown. 

Similarly, the presentation at the Huambo Museum of Art Education is divided into two sections, “The History of Works on Paper” and “Travel Sketch,” which respectively explores Ding's paper-based artistic experiments and practice and the artist’s note-like image logs made during his travels. 

The Ningbo Art Museum presentation is on view through 22 November 2023, and the presentations at the Huambo Museum of Art Education are on view through 24 March 2024.

#DingYi

“Harpies” (2000). These bronze spirits by#KikiSmith, each bearing the head of a woman and the body of a bird, were originally made for the 2002 Whitney Biennial and installed at the gates of the Central Park Zoo to look down upon entering visitors. In Greek mythology, these female deities were powerful hounds of Zeus with malevolent reputations, but Smith complicates this narrative by allowing these watchful spirits to be intimidating without forcing scale or typical expressions of menace.

Kiki Smith’s psychologically charged figurative sculptures explore themes of life, death, and resurrection. Using imagery drawn from myth, folklore, and her own personal constellation of references, Smith excavates the body, foregrounding its intrinsic properties while presenting it as a site of transformation.

The most comprehensive museum exhibition of Antoni Tàpies in Asia, "Dialogue with Objects" is now open at the Shanghai Bund Art Center.

Bringing together works made throughout the artist's career, this exhibition focuses on Tàpies’ contribution to the advancement of Modern art through theory and investigations into nontraditional materials. A prolific art theorist, Tàpies believed in the transcendental power inherent to the act of creation. The exhibition highlights the artist’s synthesis of high art with everyday materials and pays homage to his last significant solo show in China, a 1989 retrospective at the National Art Museum of China.

Tap the link in our bio to learn more.

@TMagazine: “In 2013, his instinct for collecting odds and ends led Martinez to making sculptures, at first assembling them from household objects and beachside trash. Soon, he decided to cast the pieces in bronze, often painting on top of the metallic surfaces.—Phoebe Chen @NYTimes

In “Enough,” Eddie Martinez’s current exhibition in our London gallery showcases his paintings, alongside sculptures—a medium that the artist sees as an extension of his painting practice.

Martinez cuts, pastes, and reforms material fragments and found objects into sculptural forms which are then cast in bronze and painted. Making selections in an environment, homing in on objects, and editing and breaking things down into shapes are at the heart of his practice as he explores different textures, mediums, and materials. 

On view through 18 November 2023, tap the link in our bio to plan your visit.

We are pleased to announce the representation of Sean Landers (@seanland81) in London in collaboration with Petzel Gallery. The gallery will present an exhibition of new work by the artist in London in spring 2024. 

Landers’s conceptual approach to painting alternately draws from his life experience and canonical references. His work features an arsenal of idiosyncratic personae that have personal resonance: marooning mariners, clowns, and animals both wild and domesticated. In depictions of natural disasters, the artist has shifted his practice to sardonic critiques of the ongoing climate crisis. In the tradition of Winslow Homer, his recent work fixates on maritime subjects, including boats, lighthouses, whale skeletons, and the sea itself. Landers’s diaristic, text-based paintings were instrumental in defining the art landscape of the 1990s, and he has continued to employ text throughout his career, both alone and in darkly poetic conversation with his subjects. His deeply empathetic figurative works shine a searing light on both our collective insecurities and the artist’s own. 

Tap the link in our bio to learn more about Landers.

#SeanLanders #TimothyTaylor

Sculpted in plaster or cast in bronze, Annie Morris’s (@annie_morris_studio) sculptures—currently on view at our New York gallery—are painted with hand-sourced, raw pigments in vivid hues, giving each orb a rich and vibrant color.

Over the years, Morris has developed a technique layering grains of sand and plaster to create painterly surfaces in which the hue of the raw pigment is intensified. The resulting texture emphasises the fragility of her medium—appearing as if it might slake if disturbed—and yet harnesses the vital impact of the pure pigment.

Her treatment of pigment evolves in her bronze sculptures, where the painted surfaces of the cool bronze produce a dusty glimmer. Where the plaster works suggest ephemerality, the bronze sculptures appear impermeable and enduring.

Tap the link in bio to learn more and plan your visit.

Michel Pérez Pollo (@michelperezpollo) takes us into his studio in Madrid, ahead of his upcoming exhibition in London and shares how poetry influences his practice.

Opening on 30 November, the artist’s first solo exhibition with the gallery debuts new paintings depicting surreal still-lifes of biomorphic forms captured in states of precarious balance.

Using light, shadow, shape, and colour, the artist considers the way objects generate poetry when they are placed in relation to each other and how these juxtapositions impact our perceptions.

“Two Poets” will be on view at Timothy Taylor in London with an opening reception on 30 November from 6 – 8 PM.

Wishing a happy birthday to Antonia Showering (@antoniashowering) who was born on this day in London, England! 

To celebrate, we’re highlighting “Antonia Showering: Mixed Emotion,” the artist’s inaugural exhibition with Timothy Taylor in London last year.

The exhibition presented vivid, large-scale paintings that were filled with figures Showering calls ‘the people I love or have loved.’ 

Working from abstraction back toward figuration, the artist allows a base layer of paint to pool in configurations dictated by gravity. Showering’s figures appear to slide in and out of their surroundings, while specific elements—rolling hills, mountains or lakes in a landscape, or pieces of furniture—collapse into fluid pools of paint.

Follow the link in bio to learn more.

“Tàpies. Woods, Papers, Cardboards and Collages” features early works by Antoni Tàpies including cardboards, papers, wood works, and collages that took place at the Sala Gaspar, Barcelona. Closely linked to collage and assemblage, Tàpies’s works from the ‘60s and ‘70s explore the use of materials like paper and cardboard, which for Tàpies evoked important themes of humility, fragility, and simplicity.

Demonstrating myriad approaches to the medium, this presentation explores painting as a form, a language, and a practice with the survey format underscoring the many concepts and strategies present-day artists employ.

#KikiSmith: “Art isn’t a stand-in for something. It offers the potential for experience. It’s not about something. It is something. It is a proof in itself.”

“Deep inside my heart” brings together new acquisitions and key works from the National Gallery of Australia’s (@nationalgalleryaus) collection by major women artists of the twentieth and twenty-first centuries. Exploring representations of the figure across all media, these artists’ works refer to a key period of the 1980s when representations of the body were used to assert politics, gender and identity.

Halfway between printmaking and sculpture, Kiki Smith’s tapestries, “Sky,” “Earth,” and “Underground,” highlight the artist’s approach to printmaking and multiples. Featuring life-size naked human figures, the tapestries explore the boundaries between human, flora, and fauna within the realm of myth and animalistic spiritual traditions.

Learn more at the link in bio.

"Animal Kingdom"—Sean Landers’s (@seanland81) first institutional show in France since 2020—is now on view at Musée de la Chasse et la Nature (@museechassenature). This major exhibition showcases some thirty works—including two bronze sculptures and three works created especially for this presentation— featuring the artist’s portraits of animals and the natural environment and staged throughout the museum’s collections.

Influenced by Renaissance portraiture and Surrealism, Landers blends reality and fantasy in his paintings, adding Scottish tartan plaid patterns to the coats of animals in naturalistic landscapes.

"Doing figurative painting when I was in art school was the wrong choice to make at the time, when we were being taught minimal and conceptual art. We thought it was absurd, laughable, and so of course, how could I resist it?"

Tap the link in our bio to learn more and plan your visit over the holidays.

#SeanLanders

Michel Pérez Pollo’s luminous, surreal still-life paintings recall the artist’s upbringing in Cuba. This experience informed his understanding of objects; he sees the ways in which they are unfixed and adaptable, according to context and perception. In his work, he considers how these objects generate poetry when they are placed in relation to each other and the way these juxtapositions impact our inner worlds. 

“We live for the moment, and there is no great concern for the future, as the present is a full challenge”—@michelperezpollo

Learn more about this presentation at the link in bio and plan your visit today before the gallery closes for the holidays.

Hilary Pecis reinterprets the Lady Dior handbag.

For its 8th edition, @hilary_pecis created her own take on the #DiorLadyArt limited-edition bag. Blending heritage with her own creative vision, Pecis’s design integrates nature motifs inspired by childhood memories of playing with her grandmother’s jewellery box. Embroidered flowers, intricate beadings, and gold charms transform the Lady Dior into a work of art.

Launched at Art Basel Miami Beach earlier this month, the handbag is available at Dior stores for a limited time.

Don't miss the final days to see a major retrospective of work by #AntoniTàpies at @bozarbrussels. Coinciding with the centenary of Tàpies's birth, "Antoni Tàpies: The Practice of Art," celebrates the life and work of the artist with more than 120 works, which include paintings, sculptures, and drawings. 

On view through Sunday 7 January 2024, this exhibition offers a rare glimpse into one of the most influential artists of the 20th century. Learn more at the link in bio.

This year, we reopened our New York gallery in Tribeca, hosted ambitious projects, and celebrated our artists many achievements in 2023. Join us as we look back on a landmark year at Timothy Taylor!

Sunday is the last chance to see Annie Morris’s two-person presentation at @Pitzhanger Manor & Gallery. Shown alongside artist and life partner Idris Khan, “When Loss Makes Melodies” is imbued with themes of emotion, time, and memory.

The exhibition includes over thirty works and engages in a dialogue with the space’s neoclassical architecture, designed by Sir John Soane, showcasing a range of art forms from sculpture and photography to painting and embroidery. 

Plan your visit before the exhibition closes on 7 January.
