These intimately scaled paintings by Michel Pérez Pollo (@michelperezpollo), currently on view in London through 20 January, showcase the artist’s biomorphic forms in his subtle technique of creating fresco-matte surfaces. Layering colour upon colour, Pérez Pollo develops the surface of his paintings, leaving passages where raw canvas is exposed, as well as drips, stains, and other evidence of the painterly process. 

Learn more about the artist’s debut solo exhibition with the gallery at the link in bio.

#MichelPerezPollo #TimothyTaylor

Michel Pérez Pollo, “Un Otoño XXIII,” 2023; “Un Otoño XXIV,” 2023

Two exhibitions showcasing the legacy of Antoni Tàpies closes on Sunday at @BozarBrussels and Shanghai Bund Art Center. 

Coinciding with the centenary of Tàpies’s birth, both presentations offer an overview of the artist’s practice and explore the artist’s use of materials and technique throughout his career. 

 “Antoni Tàpies. The Practice of Art.” at Bozar Centre for Fine Arts is the first Tàpies retrospective in Belgium in almost 40 years, while “Dialogue with Objects” at the Shanghai Bund Art Center is his most comprehensive museum exhibition in Asia. 

“In the year in which we celebrate the centenary of his birth… this seems a good moment to reflect once again on his visual and essayistic creations and to view them with a fresh perspective. His work is truly contemporary, imbued with concerns about human dramas, injustices, and the irrational exploitation of nature, all more relevant and poignant than ever before. Yet, it is also suffused with love, freedom, and the beauty we can discover in seemingly simple things.” —Toni Tàpies, son of the artist

#AntoniTapies #TimothyTaylor @fundacioantonitapies

Repetition is a fundamental aspect of Alex Katz’s practice which is explored in “Alex Katz: Repetitions” at the Colby College Museum of Art (@colbymuseum) through four elements: reflection, recurrence, reduplication, and re-creation. Featuring a selection from the museum’s collection of nearly nine hundred of the artist’s artworks, the installation highlights how Katz uses each of these elements of repetition as tools for observing the world and connecting to it intentionally.

Tap the link in our bio to learn more about the show.

Installation view, “Alex Katz: Repetitions,” Colby College Museum of Art, 2023. Photo: Luc Demers

Tàpies’s Year at @FundacióAntoniTàpies continues with two exhibitions: “Tàpies. The Zen Imprint” and “A=A, B=B.”

Curated by Núria Homs, “The Zen Imprint” investigates the influence of Japanese monks of the eighteenth- and nineteenth-centuries and teachings of Zen Buddhism on the artist’s work. The exhibition explores how Tàpies integrated many of the attitudes, images, and techniques of traditional Japanese artists and culture.

“A=A, B=B” takes “A New Vision of the World” (1954), a book of lectures on science and essays that deeply influence Tàpies as a starting point to reflect on the links between art and science. Curated by the artist and scientist Pep Vidal, the exhibition addresses the spirit of the scientific method; the human desire to pursue science; and what science means in relation to ourselves and to art.

Learn more about these exhibitions and the year-long programmes for Tàpies’s Year at the link in our bio.

#AntoniTapies #AnyTapies
—
Antoni Tàpies, “Calligrafia vermella,” 1979 © Comissió Tàpies / Vegap. Photo: FotoGasull

“When I'm folding, I am objective and that allows me to forget myself.”
—Simon Hantaï

Our first exhibition of 2024 in New York will be a presentation of paintings by Simon Hantaï, many of which have not been previously shown in the United States. Curated by Molly Warnock (@molly.warnock), the exhibition features ten canvases spanning more than two decades, offering a nuanced and comprehensive view of the artist’s innovative body of work. Join us for the opening reception on Thursday 25 January from 6–8pm.

Learn more about this presentation at the link in bio. 

#SimonHantai #TimothyTaylor

There are just a few days left to see Daniel Crews-Chubb’s (@danielcrewschubb) work in “Ashmolean NOW” at the @ashmoleanmuseum!

These works, made specifically for this two-person museum exhibition, alongside Flora Yukhnovich, convey a timeless passion for the medium of painting, its materials, and process. Taking inspiration from ancient sculptures of deities and non-human figures found in the Ashmolean, Crews-Chubb’s new “immortals” series comprises large-scale paintings of fantastical figures created through a laborious process of addition and revision including drawing, impasto, and collage.

The accompanying exhibition catalogue, designed as two books in one, features works by both artists and includes interviews with each artist and curator Lena Fritch. 

“Ashmolean NOW: Flora Yukhnovich x Daniel Crews-Chubb” is open through 14 January. Learn more at the link in bio. 

#DanielCrewsChubb #Ashmolean

Happy birthday to Michel Pérez Pollo (@michelperezpollo), who was born on this day, 12 January, in Manzanillo, Cuba!

Don’t miss the chance to see Pérez Pollo’s first exhibition with the gallery since his representation announcement earlier this year, on view in London through 25 January. Attuned to beauty and balance, the artist orchestrates light, shadow, shape, and color into a very singular visual poetry in “Two Poets.”

Tap the link in bio to learn more. 

#MichelPerezPollo #TimothyTaylor
__
Portrait of Michel Pérez Pollo. Photo: Flavia Fuentes

Wishing a happy birthday to Sahara Longe (@saharalonge) who was born on this day in London, England!

The artist will be presenting new work at Timothy Taylor in Tribeca this spring which will mark her second exhibition with the gallery and first in New York following her first solo show in London last year.

#SaharaLonge #TimothyTaylor
__
The artist in the studio, Suffolk, UK, November 2023. Photo: Ollo Weguelin © Sahara Longe

Happy birthday, Annie Morris, who was born on this day, 16 January, in London, England!

This photo of the artist was captured at Morris’s recent exhibition in New York, “Permanent Moments,” which featured new sculptures and tapestries by the artist. Adding hues of muted turquoise, lavender, and oxblood red to her signature palette of ultramarine blue, viridian, and ochre, Morris experiments with texture and pigment harnessing the vital impact of the pure pigment.

#AnnieMorris #TimothyTaylor 
__
Installation view of Annie Morris in “Permanent Moments,” Timothy Taylor, New York, November 2023. Photo: @annie_morris_studio

Cuban artist Michel Pérez Pollo’s abstract-figurative works provide a glimpse into the artist’s understanding of objects. The artist’s new exhibition “Two Poets”—which continues this exploration—closes at our London gallery through Saturday 25 January. 

Step inside the artist’s Madrid studio as Pérez Pollo channels the Surrealist method of automatism to create models using miniature plasticine and found-objects. He then translates these compositions—captured in states of precarious balance—on to canvas.

Tap the link in our bio to learn more about the artist’s practice and his first solo presentation with the gallery in London. 

#MichelPerezPollo #TimothyTaylor @michelperezpollo 
__
Video: @ceniza_tv

#KikiSmith: “My suffering is that I see that there are these really great forms. They’re holy in a way, like they have this really incredible power about them. And all I can do is recognize it.”

Happy birthday to Kiki Smith, who was born on this day, 18 January 1954, in Nuremberg, Germany!

Widely recognized for her multidisciplinary practice through which she explores the human condition, Smith has long been interested in our most basic relation to the world we live in.

Life, death, and resurrection are thematic signposts in Smith’s expansive oeuvre, which extends to sculpture, painting, printmaking, textiles, installation, and photography. Using imagery drawn from myth, folklore, and her own personal constellation of references, Smith excavates the body, foregrounding its intrinsic properties while presenting it as a site of transformation.
__
Kiki Smith, “Cathedral (Wolf) (detail),” 2013 © Kiki Smith

In two weeks, "Jorge Eielson: Room in Rome" will open at Timothy Taylor in London. 

This year marks the centenary of Jorge Eielson, a Peruvian painter and writer whose work straddled multiple genres, from Modernist abstraction to Arte Povera and conceptualism, over his six decade-long career. 

Presented in collaboration with the Jorge Eielson Archive and Study Center, "Room in Rome" centres on a critical moment in Jorge Eielson’s career and situtates his work alongside the international artists he encountered during this period.

Learn more about the exhibition, and join us for the opening reception on 1 February from 6–8pm.

#JorgeEielson #TimothyTaylor
__
Portrait of Jorge Eielson, 1970s © 2024 Jorge Eielson Study Center
